DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China trade announcement is coming after the market close and that he has great respect for Chinese President Xi but the US trade deficit is too big and 'we can't do that anymore'. Conversely, some twitter sources noted reports that US President Trump also stated that China 'wants to make a deal', while there were also reports China is said to cancel trade talks if US President Trump moves ahead with tariffs. (Newswires/Twitter)


UK

UK PM May said that there would be disruption in the event of a no-deal Brexit but the UK must make a success of a no deal outcome. (Newswires)

EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier said that a Brexit deal is possible if the integrity of the single market is preserved. (Newswires)

Senior EU diplomats are said to anticipate the UK government will have to go through its darkest hour and stare into the abyss of a no-deal Brexit before it will give in to EU demands. (Guardian)

EU is said to prepare emergency laws in case of a hard-Brexit. (Handelsblatt)


EU

ECB's Coeure said ECB may have to further clarify the pace at which it expects to remove policy accommodation and that if economic conditions warrant, there might be a case for the Governing Council to go beyond the timing to lift-off. Coeure also commented that the uncertainty around the inflation outlook is receding and a sustained convergence of inflation to levels closer to our aim is in sight. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Russia's Energy Minister Novak said he may discuss the possibility of increasing output by more than 1mln BPD at the upcoming OPEC meeting. (Newswires)


US

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the US is ready to negotiate with China anytime if they are ready for serious and substantive talks. Kudlow also said US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is in touch and is negotiating with Chinese officials, while he forecasts more progress on trade with Canada, EU and Japan. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said Canada will stand up for Canada's system of dairy protections at NAFTA talks, while there were also reports that Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland is set to continue talks with US Trade Representative Lighthizer this week. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

US stocks finished lower with sentiment dampened on tariff-related fears after US President Trump declared he will be making an announcement regarding China after the market close. This pressured all US majors with the NASDAQ 100 the worst hit amid underperformance in tech and with AMZN hit on weekend news that the tech giant is investigating claims that staff leaked data in exchange for bribes. AAPL is said to be spared tariffs on its Watches, which helped lift its stock off session lows. While some reports suggested traders were booking profits as trade tensions, the downside in the tech giants in turn pressured the tech complex early in the cash day, setting a negative tone. Chip names were also subject to the trade fears theme. TWTR was hit after a downgrade at Moffett Nathanson. In M&A, DOJ has cleared Cigna’s (CI) acquisition of Express Scripts (ESRX), sending the latter surging higher. In other M&A, US DOJ of CVS (CVS) planned acquisition of Aetna (AET) could be concluded by the end of the month, sources say. KR was higher after announcing a new fashion line. SPX -0.6% at 2888, NDX -1.5% at 7434, DJI -0.4% at 26062.

There was much fanfare as 10-year yields once again crossed 3.00% to the upside as the Treasury complex was being sold pre-market (sympathy with bunds was also cited). However, as tech sold-off at the open, and a general fear of trade war escalation lingering in trader’s minds, there was buying action pushing yields back beneath the psychological 3.00% handle. The story remains the same in the short-end with 2-year yields printing fresh decade+ highs. At settlement, however, yields were relatively unchanged on the day, and the curve had very, very modestly steepened. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 1+ ticks lower at 119-04.

UBS Weekly FX flows: GBP and NOK heavily bought while SEK and CHF most sold
content: "GBP recorded the highest inflows among G10 currencies on a normalized basis as Brexit headlines offered some relief. GBP experienced its strongest inflows on Tuesday as the UK employment report showed real earnings edging higher. NOK was bought for a second straight week as core inflation rose sharply in August. AUD was also bought for a second week, with heavy inflows coinciding with strong August labour data. EUR saw inflows as the ECB remained essentially on auto-pilot, maintaining that risks to its outlook are 'broadly balanced'. CAD was bought for the first time in five weeks as NAFTA talks continued. SEK led G10 outflows, experiencing selling all week as heaviest outflows coincided with weaker than expected inflation data. CHF was sold for a third week while JPY extended outflows to a fifth week. USD experienced selling with largest outflows on Thursday, coinciding with CPI missing consensus expectations."

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 17th September 2018 - US TO MAKE CHINA TRADE ANNOUNCEMENT AFTER MARKET CLOSE
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries flat, crude down, dollar down.
  • REAR-VIEW: US to announce measures on China trade after market.
  • AHEAD: RBA minutes, NBH rate decision, API inventories, GDT auction, ECB’s Draghi, Villeroy and Nuoy.

* NOTE: Monday’s market wrap is being published early since US President Trump will be making an announcement on China trade after the market close.

* TRADE: US President Trump last Thursday reportedly instructed his aides to go ahead with tariffs on $200bln of Chinese imports, though an announcement was said to be delayed as the administration considers feedback received in the public consultations; reports suggest that the rate of the tariff could be at 10% rather than the 25% touted thus far (which would also be slightly beneath market expectations, some desks have noted), and an announcement is expected within the coming days. However, that better than expected development was offset by a negative update from China; the WSJ reported that China is set to rebuff US overtures to resume trade talks after the fresh threat of tariffs from the US. On Monday, President Trump once again talked-up the tool of imposing tariffs, tweeting that tariffs have put the US in a very strong bargaining position, "and yet cost increases have thus far been almost unnoticeable," and added that "if countries will not make fair deals with us, they will be 'tariffed'." NEC Director Kudlow, speaking at the economic club of New York, said an announcement on the additional $200bln tariffs on China imports could be forthcoming soon, noting the US is ready negotiate with China anytime if they are ready for serious and substantive talks. He also reported to be constantly assessing the effects of tariffs on prices and noted US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is in touch and is negotiating with Chinese officials, though Trump has not been satisfied with China talks so far. Separately, Kudlow anticipates more progress on trade with Canada, the EU and Japan.

* BREXIT: Both sides expressed optimism on a Brexit deal on Monday as EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier said Brexit talks are progressing in spirit of good cooperation, UK PM May Spokesman stated they are confident of reaching a Brexit deal and UK PM May stressed that it is now for the EU to respond to the proposals made by the UK, urging not to fall back on previous positions as she looks forward to agreeing on a good deal for the UK. As part of considerations to "de-dramatise" Brexit, Brussels and Ireland are discussing proposals to make British officials (as opposed to EU inspectors) responsible for checking goods coming into Northern Ireland. Over the weekend, former UK Foreign Secretary Johnson used an op-ed in the Telegraph to once again criticise PM May's Chequers Plan, though former Cabinet member and Brexiteer Gove in a weekend interview suggested that the plan will do for now, and that MPs could change the details in the future. Nonetheless, the Irish border remains a key sticking point in negotiations after the EU was secretly said to be prepared to accept a frictionless Irish border after Brexit in a move that raises the prospect of PM May striking a deal by the end of the year. Following the news, Northern Ireland's DUP deputy leader said it is imperative EU negotiators clarify revised backstop proposal as soon as possible as they will not accept anything that creates barriers within the UK and are unconvinced of a technological border. Finally, reports in Handelsblatt said the EU is to prepare emergency laws in case of a hard-Brexit.

* FED: The San Fran Fed, which votes in 2018, has appointed Mary Daly as new President, effective 1 October, replacing the departed John Williams, who now heads-up the NY Fed. Deutsche Bank’s analysts argue that her labour economist background will likely be a dovish voice in the room. Daly was said to sound optimistic on the economy in a recent speech, the bank notes, and appeared to be less concerned with softer wage readings than other doves, with Deutsche Bank suggesting that she seems more inclined to let the economy run hotter.   

* US NY FED MANUFACTURING fell short of expectations and posted at 19 in September, consensus was for 23. Pantheon suggested that the figure was disappointing, particularly after a very solid ISM Manufacturing for August. Looking at the breakdown, shipments fell sharply, immediately followed by new orders and delivery which also posted a drop. Pantheon expects the data to augur a soft September Manufacturing PMI, though stresses that the two data points don’t always move together. Their view, however, is that “the rate of growth of output likely has peaked for this cycle but we see no evidence that a real slowdown is underway.”

* STOCK SPECIFICS: AMZN was hit on weekend news that the tech giant is investigating claims that staff leaked data in exchange for bribes. AAPL is said to be spared tariffs on its Watches, which helped lift its stock off session lows. While some reports suggested traders were booking profits as trade tensions, the downside in the tech giants in turn pressured the tech complex early in the cash day, setting a negative tone. Chip names were also subject to the trade fears theme. TWTR was hit after a downgrade at Moffett Nathanson. In M&A, DOJ has cleared Cigna’s (CI) acquisition of Express Scripts (ESRX), sending the latter surging higher. In other M&A, US DOJ of CVS (CVS) planned acquisition of Aetna (AET) could be concluded by the end of the month, sources say. KR was higher after announcing a new fashion line.

* WTI (V8) SETTLES $0.08 LOWER AT $68.91/BBL; BRENT (X8) SETTLES $0.04 LOWER AT $78.05/BBL. Ahead of OPEC’s meeting in Algiers on 23 September. Crude was trading lower on Monday. The meeting was initially intended to be a simple review of production data by monitoring committees, however, it has taken on more significance, and the members will be able to put forward and discuss multiple scenarios, according to Russia’s energy minister Novak (who said he may discuss lifting production by more than 1mln BPD, as set out by OPEC/OPEC+). Citi’s analysts would be surprised to see any fresh decisions on production policy until the full regular summit, which is scheduled for 3 December. “Among other issues, we think the group will want to have more information on the impact of US sanctions on Iranian oil production. Russia’s Novak expects compliance with the OPEC/OPEC+ output deal to be running at 108% in August (monitoring committees estimated 109% in July).

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 1+ TICKS LOWER AT 191-04. There was much fanfare as 10-year yields once again crossed 3.00% to the upside as the Treasury complex was being sold pre-market (sympathy with bunds was also cited). However, as tech sold-off at the open, and a general fear of trade war escalation lingering in trader’s minds, there was buying action pushing yields back beneath the psychological 3.00% handle. The story remains the same in the short-end with 2-year yields printing fresh decade+ highs. At settlement, however, yields were relatively unchanged on the day, and the curve had very, very modestly steepened.


* USD: There is not much on the slate this week that will * provide a catalyst for the USD to break away from consolidating in the 94.50-95.50 bracket, save the trade war tape bombs that have led to USD strength when there is a threat of escalation. That has left some desks to think about the stretched USD long positions, as reported in the CFTC data on Friday. SocGen's FX strategists have suggested it may be wise to hedge long USD positions into year-end, arguing that a fair amount of the USD-positive news is priced in. "With the US economy doing well, the Fed on track to hike twice more this year and US trade policy inviting parallels with Florence and Mangkhut, there’s support for the dollar but the uptrend is in final stages." 

* EUR: EUR was unable to sustainably break above 1.17 to the upside last week, confined by range-bound trade; and despite the USD weakness against majors on Monday, the single currency found the air thin around that level. The single currency is also being supported by positive news on the Italian budget front, but fears of trade conflict escalations has kept some interest in the USD, capping the EUR's upside, given the tendency of the USD to usually appreciate amid Trade Wars headlines, and of course, the strong ties the EZ economy shares with China. "We think that EUR will remain generally more resilient than other G10 currencies in the face of growing threat of escalating trade conflict between the US and China," Credit Agricole says. "In particular, EUR should continue to benefit from evidence that the US and the EU have started moving closer to a trade deal and/or that the Italian government comes up with a budget proposal on 27 September that respects the EU rules." Additionally, although the ECB cut its near-term growth forecasts based on trade conflicts last week, President Draghi still sounded upbeat on the prospects for the economy, and stressed that the economy can remain resilient in the face of persistent global headwinds. However, some desks warn that the Italian Saga will unlikely be a straightforward affair, and warn about chasing EUR higher on this theme alone. 

* NOK: The Norwegian Krone was the top G10 performer on Monday, ahead of the Norges Bank rate decision on Thursday, where it is expected to lift rates for the first time in seven years. Nordea also looks for the central bank to lift its rate path through 2019 on the back of strong underlying inflation, weaker than expected NOK, as well as positive dynamics in the oil sector.

* CAD: The Loonie traded flat/slight higher against its US counterpart, taking its cue from some upbeat NAFTA comments, as well as a cue from positive oil moves in the afternoon, after Genscape was reported to forecast a draw of 2.2mln barrels at Cushing this week. Other than that, analysts say that to meaningfully break beneath the 1.30, trade headlines will need to provide support.

* GBP: Noises that the EU is becoming more flexible within Brexit negotiations has been supporting GBP ahead of Brexit talks later this week, which has seen policymakers express optimism. The weaker USD was also benefiting sterling on Monday, with cable back to the 1.3150 area, and EURGBP probing ground sub-0.89.

* AUD: Ahead of the RBA meeting minutes overnight, Aussie trades firm, shrugging off fears of trade war escalation. However, the Aussies’ strength may have been more a function of the USD selling against the majors.  With regards to the RBA, the central bank is not expected to hike any time soon, and as such, traders will be focusing on the guidance aspects of the release, particularly on mortgage rates, after a number of Australian banks have lifted SVR in recent weeks.

Daily FX Wrap: Usd yields more ground to major currency counterparts, but not all
content:
DXY

It’s been a gradual drift down, and perversely perhaps contrary to a steady grind higher in US Treasury yields (10 year benchmark back above 3%), but the index and Greenback in general have continued to pull-back from last week’s ‘closing’ levels and the DXY is now revisiting 94.500 almost 95.000 at best ahead of Monday’s EU open. Note, the index hit a recent low of around 94.350, and this now forms the nearest downside objective, if not chart support in the technical sense.

GBP/NZD/EUR/AUD/CHF/SEK/NOK  

A few changes within the ranks, but all extending gains and outperformance vs the Dollar, or against Eur in the case of the Sek and Nok. Cable benefited from more positive Brexit news to rebound towards 1.3150, while Eur/Gbp slipped back below 0.8900 amidst reports that the EU is open to a frictionless Irish border and UK officials overseeing customs checks on goods heading in to Northern Ireland. This, and an upbeat Buba monthly report also underpinned Eur/Usd, with the headline pair extending its rebound through 1.1650 and not far from 1.1700 where decent option expiry interest (1.3 bn) runs off at the NY cut. The Aud and Nzd also pared more losses vs their US peer from sub-0.7150 and 0.6550 overnight lows made after US President Trump threatened to action the pending $200 bn import tariffs on Chinese goods (albeit at 10% initially vs 25% proposed) to revisit levels not far from 0.7200 and 0.6600, while the Franc strengthened from circa 0.9680 to around 0.9620 ahead of Thursday’s SNB quarterly policy review. Turning to the Scandis, both derived more traction on Central Bank dynamics with a Norges Bank widely if not universally expected this week (also Thursday) and minutes from the Riksbank underscoring guidance for tightening in either December or February 2019. Eur/Nok probing under 9.5550, Eur/Sek below 10.4450.

CAD/JPY   

Relative G10 laggards all day, with the Loonie capped below 1.3000, albeit just and Usd/Jpy pivoting around 112.00, with a lack of fresh news/progress on NAFTA and Japanese markets observing a public holiday.

EM

The Try back in the spotlight and succumbing to renewed selling pressure ahead of Turkey’s medium term economic plan later this week, with only brief respite from better than forecast ip data. Lira now licking wounds around 6.3000 vs the Usd, while the Rand recovered from 15.0000+ lows vs the Usd ahead of SA August inflation data, the SARB policy meeting and President Ramaphosa pledging no mass public sector lay-offs.

Separately, the tech titan has said, in a reply to a customer complaint, that they do not delete movies its customers have already downloaded. (DigiTimes/Newswires)
  • DowDuPont (DWDP) –The chemical co. has announced the senior leaders of the independent co.s that will be created when the Agriculture and Speciality Products Division is separated. CEO Edward Breen will become executive chairman of the speciality products co. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – EU antitrust regulators will decide on October 19th whether to clear the USD 7.5bln acquisition of privately held coding website GitHub. (Newswires)
  • Pfizer (PFE) – The pharma giant announced its phase 2a study in alopecia areata met primary endpoints. The Phase 2a study of PF-06651600, an oral Janus kinase 3 inhibitor, and PF-06700841, a tyrosine kinase 2/JAK1 inhibitor, compared to placebo, in patients with alopecia areata, an autoimmune disease. Separately, Pfizer entered into an evaluation agreement with Atomwise, a platform for the identification of potential drug candidates for up to three target proteins selected by the co. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The Flipkart unit is in talks to acquire a stake in Star India’s streaming service Hostar stepping up its competition battle with Amazon (AMZN). (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Alaska Air (ALK) - Reports August traffic up 3.8%, capacity up 4.3%. (Newswires)
  • Allergan (AGN) – The pharma co. announced clinical results of higher doses of BOTOX Cosmetic compared to BOTOX Cosmetic 20 unit dose at week 24 in patients with moderate to severe glabellar lines. The study met its primary endpoint. (Newswires)
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – The packaged food co. and activist investor Third Point (TPRE) have filed a preliminary proxy material urging shareholders to vote in favour of two entirely different lists of board nominees. Campbell, which is pushing for the board to remain intact, said it did not approve any board nominees present by Third Point. (Newswires)
  • Casino names (MGM, LVS, WYNN, MLCO) - Macau's government has suspended all casino operations starting on Saturday September 15, due to safety concerns ahead of Typhoon Mangkhut storm. (Newswires)
  • Coca Cola (KO) - The soft drinks producer is eyeing the cannabis market and is in talks with cannabis producer Aurora Cannabis in a push for cannabis-infused beverages focused at easing inflammation and pain; according to sources familiar with the matter. (Newswires)
  • Duke Energy (DUK) – The utilities co. reported that more than 1mln customers in North and South Carolina have had their power restored following hurricane Florence, as of 16:00 Sunday, 404,000 customers remained without power. (Newswires)
  • Emerson (EMR) – The manufacturing co. has received an unsolicited “mini-tender” from Baker Mills for the purchase of 50,000 shares. Emerson is opposed to the offer and recommends its shareholders not to accept the offer as the offer price is below the market price. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE), Wabtec (WAB) – The railway tech co. Wabtec has said it expects its planned merger with General Electric Transportation to be completed by early 2019. (Newswires)
  • Hilton (HLT) – The hotel chain formed an alliance with Playa Hotels & Resorts (PLYA) aimed at accelerating Hilton’s growth of all-inclusive resorts. (Newswires)
  • Mastercard (MA)/Visa (V) – Goldman Sachs added Mastercard to its Conviction list maintaining a buy rating and raising its price target to USD 260 from USD 230. Goldman Sachs however removed Visa (V) from its Conviction list but kept a buy rating on the shares. (Newswires)
  • Mylan (MYL) – The healthcare group and Theravance Biopharma (TBPH) announced positive new data from Phase 3 clinical program for YUPELRI inhalation solution were featured in a presentation at the European Respiratory Society International Congress 2018. (Newswires)
  • NiSource (NI) – The co.’s unit, Columbia Gas of Massachusetts, has said restoration efforts are continuing following Thursday’s gas explosion in Merrimack Valley, residents are beginning to return home as power is being restored. (Newswires)
  • Northrop Grumman (NOC) – The aerospace co. announced the successful launch of its ICESat-2 spacecraft. (Newswires)
  • Sempra Energy (SRE) – The nat. gas co. has announced Lisa Glatch as its new strategic initiatives officer. (Newswires)
  • Sysco (SYY) – The co. names CEO Tom Bene as chairman and announces Jackie Ward will retire from the co.’s board. (Newswires)
  • Travelers (TRV), AIG (AIG), Allstate (ALL) – Barron’s wrote that the insurers won’t face much difficulty in repairing the damages from hurricane Florence due to the large amount of available capital they are sitting on; approximately half a trillion. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – The social media co.’s conservative leaning employees don’t feel safe to express their opinions, that is according to CEO Jack Dorsey. (Newswires)
  • Tyson Foods (TSN) – The packaged food co.’s CEO, Tom Hayes, has announced his resignation and Noel White is to succeed. Backs FY18 EPS view USD 5.70-6.00, consensus USD 5.89. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – Google has developed a prototype of a censored search engine for Chinese users that ties Android searches to the phone number of the individual.
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailer titan has reported it is investigating employees for potential data leeks for bribes, particularly in Shenzen, China. Elsewhere, the co. has opened “Amazon Storefronts”, a new store for customers to shop from U.S. small and medium sized businesses. The co.’s Amazon India has begun planning to start selling life, health and general insurance. (Newswires)
  • eBay (EBAY) – The e-commerce giant’s StubHub is no longer the official ticket reseller for AEG’s venues after its contract expired this summer. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media co. is said to be looking to hire a Director of Human Rights Policy. (Newswires)
  • Micron (MU) - BMO cuts price target to USD 45 from USD 63. (Newswires)
  • Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Sanofi (SNY) – The two pharma co.s announced results from their Phase 3 trial showing Dupixent monotherapy demonstrated a "significant improvement" in signs and symptoms of atopic dermatitis and certain quality of life measures in adolescent patients with moderate-to-severe atopic dermatitis. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – California’s Division of Occupational Safety and Health has opened two inspections on the automaker following incidents at their factories. The CEO, Elon Musk, also tweeted how the co. was bringing most collision repairs in-house to improve efficiency. Elsewhere, a fire had broken out in the co.’s Nevada Gigafactory over the weekend, though the fire was short-lived and production continued shortly after. He also added the co. was in delivery logistics hell but the co. was making rapid progress on the issue (Newswires)   
  • Twenty-First Century Fox Inc (FOXA) – EU antitrust regulators have set a deadline for their ruling on of Disney's USD 71.3bln bid for Fox's assets on October 19th. The European Commission could clear the deal with or without concessions or open a four-month long investigation if it has serious concerns. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Altaba (AABA) – The investment co. has made a settlement agreement in its Yahoo data breach lawsuit. (Newswires)
  • BeiGene (BGNE) – The Chinese pharma co. has announced four oral clinical data presentations on two of its late-stage therapies, tislelizumab and zanubrutinib. (Newswires)  
  • Brunswick (BC) – The conglomerate has announced the partnership of its subsidiary Mercury Marine with Dealer Spike. (Newswires)
  • Cheniere Energy (CQP) – The co. has entered a 15-year agreement for the supply of liquified gas (LNG) to Vitol, the largest oil trader, agreeing to sell 700,000 tonnes of LNG to the co. every year. (Newswires)
  • Crispr Therapeutics (CRSP) – The drug maker is entering a collaboration with ViaCyte on diabetes treatment. (Newswires)
  • Dell Technologies (DVMT) – The co. is holding an analyst meeting on Thursday on a deal to go public. (WSJ)
  • Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) – The automaker has said it is seeking other offers for its Magneti Marelli parts unit as its offer from KKR & Co. (KKR) is too low. (Newswires)
  • Government Properties (GOV), Select Income REIT (SIR) – The two co.s have announced a definitive agreement to merge as a new REIT focusing on buildings for single tenants and high credit quality tenants. (Newswires)
  • iQIYI (IQ) – The co. has announced plans to develop Chinese writer Tang Jia San Shao’s novel “Mysterious Seas and Lands of Wonder” into multiple media formats. (Newswires)
  • Nexa Resources (NEXA) - The Brazilian mining group is planning to invest USD 1.17bln in copper and zinc projects in Peru and Brazil over the next five years. (Newswires)
  • NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – The co. alongside Hitachi Solutions have announced a partnership to produce a new V2X solution. (Newswires)
  • Owens-Illinois (OI) – The glass producer gained momentum after Atlantic Investment Management sent a letter to the co.’s board calling for the sale of its European unit, which could generate profit of between USD 3.2bln-3.8bln. (Newswires)
  • Teva (TEVA) – The pharma co. has announced FDA approval of its AJOVYTM injection for the preventive treatment of migraines. (Newswires)
  • Tronc (TRNC) - The newspaper co. is in early stage talks to be acquired by competitor McClatchy. This comes after Donerail Group was announced to also be in talks to buy Tronc since early August, where they offered USD 19-20/SHR. (Newswires)
  • Wabtec (WAB) – The co. has filed a proxy statement with the SEC relating to the proposed merger with General Electric Transportation (GE) with the transaction expected to close by Q1. (Newswires)
  • XPO Logistics (XPO) – The co. is to add 8,000 seasonal jobs in North America. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

17th September 2018

US President Trump ramps up tariff talk on China, ready to go ahead with USD 200bln in tariffs, as according to source reports

Asian equities negative and European equities choppy as the tone sours; FX markets stable

Looking ahead, the highlight is US NY Fed Manufacturing

TRADE

US President Trump was said to want to go ahead with USD 200bln in China tariffs despite talks and told advisers to proceed with the tariffs according to reports on Friday which cited people familiar with the matter. Furthermore, separate reports over the weekend stated that the tariffs will go into effect within weeks and that an announcement could be made within days, while the tariffs are said to likely be set at about 10% but could be raised to 25% if China does not appear willing to comply to US trade demands at proposed meetings in Washington on September 27th-28th. Additionally US President Trump tweeted "Tariffs have put the U.S. in a very strong bargaining position" and "If countries will not make fair deals they will be “Tariffed!"" (Newswires)

China reportedly may not participate in planned trade discussions with the US if the Trump administration goes ahead with additional tariffs. (WSJ)

G-20 ministers issued statement which noted that they discussed ways to improve the WTO and that said there is urgent need to improve the WTO, while it also noted that they stepped up dialogue on international trade. G20 ministers also stated the EU-Mercosur free trade deal involving Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and Venezuela is 'in the final stages' of negotiation. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a subdued tone amid the absence of Japanese participants due to public holiday and with sentiment dampened by trade concerns after US President Trump reportedly told advisers to proceed with tariffs on a further USD 200bln of Chinese goods which could be announced as early as today. Furthermore, reports noted the tariffs could be set at about 10% and raised to 25% if China shows an unwillingness to adhere to US demands at proposed meetings later this month, while China was said to consider abandoning discussions if the US proceeds with the tariffs. This pressured both ASX 200 (+0.3%) and KOSPI (-0.7%) from the open with healthcare the underperformer in Australia as the sector faces scrutiny from a royal commission inquiry, although the index later recovered amid strength in utilities, tech and financials. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) were negative and took the brunt of the Trump tariff threats, while gambling stocks saw heavy losses after Macau shut down its casinos and floods hit the territory due to Typhoon Mangkhut.

PBoC skipped reverse repos and instead injected CNY 265bln via 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8509 (Prev. 6.8362)

Chinese House Prices (Aug) Y/Y 7.0% (Prev. 5.8%). (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

The EU is secretly preparing to accept a frictionless Irish border after Brexit in a move that raises the prospect of PM May striking a deal by the end of the year, according to Confidential diplomatic notes seen by The Times. In a concession to British concerns, EU negotiators intend to use technological solutions to minimise customs checks between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic (Times) Further to this, the FT reported that the EU are in discussions with Brussels over allowing British officials (as opposed to EU ones), to check goods bound for Northern Ireland, in a bid to unlock stalled talks on the “backstop” plan for the Irish border. (FT)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson has continued to criticise UK PM May’s Chequers proposal by stating that May was leading the nation towards a ‘spectacular political car crash’. (Newswires)

Spain are reportedly to seek concessions concerning Gibraltar in Brexit accord, according to sources. (Newswires)

London Mayor Kahn has called for a second EU referendum, criticising the government's handling of Brexit negotiations with the EU. (BBC)

UK Environment Secretary Gove has stated that MPs could undo the Chequers deal once the UK has left the EU, adding that the PM’s proposal was the “right one for now”. (Guardian)

Italy's League are looking at proposals that would give tax breaks for Italians who purchase government bonds. (Newswires)

Riksbank minutes state a majority of the Executive Board supported the picture of the economic outlook and inflation prospects described in draft Monetary Policy Report. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Makuch said he could consider leaving position early to ensure a smooth transition prior to the next election. Furthermore, Makuch stated we’re not underestimating the risks and based on what we know now, the development is stable and risks are balanced with some downside risks to GDP growth, while he added we don’t see any reason to spread a gloomy mood or panic. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure said "Looking ahead, should economic conditions warrant, there might be a case for the Governing Council to go beyond the timing to lift-off in further clarifying the pace at which it expects to remove policy accommodation". (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equites started the day negative as the negative tone driven by US-China trade concerns in Asia extended into European trade. Stocks directionless now, however, and the IBEX is outperforming, with the DAX the underperformer. The German index is being weighed on by falling Linde shares, as more divestments by Praxair may be necessary to satisfy regulatory requirements ahead of their possible tie-up.

FX

DXY - The index and broad Usd have lost some ground in early EU trade amidst a general upturn in risk sentiment/appetite, on more positive Italian fiscal vibes and latest reports about the EU looking at ways to resolve differences over the Irish border that could pave the way for a Brexit deal with the UK, or at least raise prospects of an accord. The DXY has drifted back from just a fraction below 95.000 overnight towards 94.725 after extending post-US data gains on Friday with the added impetus of President Trump upping the ante on $200 bn Chinese import tariffs.

NZD/AUD/CHF/EUR/GBP  - All firmer vs the Greenback and marginally outperforming other majors, bar the Scandi crowns that are benefiting from relative Norges Bank and Riksbank policy outlooks vs the ECB especially, but for the former also against the Fed in the very near term given overwhelming expectations for a 25 bp hike this Thursday. The Kiwi has reclaimed 0.6550+ status, the Aud is back over 0.7150 and the Franc has rebounded through 0.9650, while the single currency has bounced firmly off 10 and 21 DMAs circa 1.1616 to test offers/resistance around 1.1650 and Cable is looking at 1.3100 again. Back to the Nok and Sek, both have extended gains vs the Eur to trade around 9.5750 and 10.4750 respectively, and with the latter seemingly latching on to the more hawkish elements of latest policy meeting minutes.

JPY/CAD - Lagging G10 peers on renewed global trade jitters, with Usd/Jpy straddling 112.00 and the Loonie meandering between 1.3050-17 on no further progress towards a NAFTA deal following the latest round of talks.

EM - The Try has been back in the spotlight and renewed pressure after last week’s massive CBRT boost, with a retreat to almost 6.3000 before some losses were clawed back with the aid of better than forecast Turkish ip data.

FIXED INCOME

Ranges remain relatively tight at the core, but in rather choppy markets there are a few clearer patterns evident and perhaps becoming more pronounced. Bunds have succumbed to more downside, albeit gradually, and have now breached near term chart support around 159.12 to test underlying buying interest around 159.00 at 158.97 (-20 ticks), while Italian BTPs look a bit more comfortable above 126.00 and climbed to 126.26 at best (+106 ticks). Gilts stretched their Liffe parameters to the upside earlier, reaching 121.61 (+13 ticks vs -8 ticks at the low) for no obvious reason at the time, but have retreated since to re-test the lows, while US Treasuries have slipped to fresh overnight session lows with the 10 year yield nudging 3% again.

COMMODITIES

The oil sector is marginally positive as the USD is easing slightly, with  WTI finding some support from its 100DMA at USD 68.89, currently trading around the USD 69.50 level. Traders remain mindful of the impact of Tropical Depression Florence, as ports remain shut in North Carolina due to flooding.

Saudi Arabia Energy Minister Al-Falih and Russian counterpart Novak met over the weekend in which they pledged to continue working on cooperation.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says that Russia is ready to discuss cooperation with the US to balance the oil market, but isn't holding these discussions at the moment

In the metals scope, gold is currently benefitting from a softer dollar and US-China trade tensions, with the yellow metal lagging at the USD 1195/oz level. Base metals have dropped on increased trade concerns, with both copper and nickel both down over 1.5%.

  • US President Trump ramps up tariff talk on China, ready to go ahead with USD 200bln in tariffs, as according to source reports
  • Asian equities negative and European equities choppy as the tone sours; FX markets stable
  • Looking ahead, the highlight is US NY Fed Manufacturing

subject: Northern Ireland's DUP deputy leader says it is imperative EU negotiators clarify revised backstop proposal as soon as possible, they will not accept anything that creates barriers within the UK, and are unconvinced of a technological border
Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) are to proceed with prep work for their Traton Group IPO. IPO should be ready for markets by the end of the year
Valero's Port Arthur has restarted a small crude unit and hydrotreater as according to sources
Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Soft Amid Ongoing Trade Policy Uncertainty
content:
•   USD lower in light volume trade; near-term risk in Empire manufacturing index.
  •   CAD up vs. USD & underperforming most G10; focus on NAFTA, Friday’s data.
  •   EUR remains resilient despite record negative yield spreads; techs neut./bullish.
  •   GBP well supported above 1.31 despite ongoing Brexit-related uncertainty.
  •   JPY quiet near low; local markets closed Monday; spreads remain dominant.
  •   AUD rising modestly, around midpoint of two week range; neutral.
  •   MXN consolidating recent rally & break above 200 day MA.

Italy's top administrative court has rejected Telecom Italia (TIT IM) appeal on conspiracy contract worth EUR 925mln
EU Brexit Negotiator Barnier says Brexit talks are continuing in spirit of good cooperation
UK PM May Spokesman says they are confident of reaching a Brexit deal
Russian Energy Minister Novak says that Russia is ready to discuss cooperation with the US to balance the oil market, but isn't holding these discussions at the moment
US President Trump tweets "Tariffs have put the U.S. in a very strong bargaining position" and "If countries will not make fair deals they will be Tariffed!""

The index and broad Usd have lost some ground in early EU trade amidst a general upturn in risk sentiment/appetite, on more positive Italian fiscal vibes and latest reports about the EU looking at ways to resolve differences over the Irish border that could pave the way for a Brexit deal with the UK, or at least raise prospects of an accord. The DXY has drifted back from just a fraction below 95.000 overnight towards 94.725 after extending post-US data gains on Friday with the added impetus of President Trump upping the ante on $200 bn Chinese import tariffs.

NZD/AUD/CHF/EUR/GBP

All firmer vs the Greenback and marginally outperforming other majors, bar the Scandi crowns that are benefiting from relative Norges Bank and Riksbank policy outlooks vs the ECB especially, but for the former also against the Fed in the very near term given overwhelming expectations for a 25 bp hike this Thursday. The Kiwi has reclaimed 0.6550+ status, the Aud is back over 0.7150 and the Franc has rebounded through 0.9650, while the single currency has bounced firmly off 10 and 21 DMAs circa 1.1616 to test offers/resistance around 1.1650 and Cable is looking at 1.3100 again. Back to the Nok and Sek, both have extended gains vs the Eur to trade around 9.5750 and 10.4750 respectively, and with the latter seemingly latching on to the more hawkish elements of latest policy meeting minutes.

JPY/CAD

Lagging G10 peers on renewed global trade jitters, with Usd/Jpy straddling 112.00 and the Loonie meandering between 1.3050-25 on no further progress towards a NAFTA deal following the latest round of talks.

EM

The Try has been back in the spotlight and renewed pressure after last week’s massive CBRT boost, with a retreat to almost 6.3000 before some losses were clawed back with the aid of better than forecast Turkish ip data.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

17th September 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a subdued tone amid the absence of Japanese participants due to public holiday and with sentiment dampened by trade concerns after US President Trump reportedly told advisers to proceed with tariffs on a further USD 200bln of Chinese goods which could be announced as early as today. Furthermore, reports noted the tariffs could be set at about 10% and raised to 25% if China shows an unwillingness to adhere to US demands at proposed meetings later this month, while China was said to consider abandoning discussions if the US proceeds with the tariffs. This pressured both ASX 200 (+0.4%) and KOSPI (-0.8%) from the open with healthcare the underperformer in Australia as the sector faces scrutiny from a royal commission inquiry, although the index later recovered amid strength in utilities, tech and financials. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) were negative and took the brunt of the Trump tariff threats, while gambling stocks saw heavy losses after Macau shut down its casinos and floods hit the territory due to Typhoon Mangkhut.

FTSE

BAE Systems (BA/ LN) – Investors are growing concerned over a lack of updates over the BAE-Qatar deal for GBP 5bln of Typhoon aircraft. This has already been pushed back twice, and prior to the deal the co. was set to cut production and hundreds of jobs in the UK. (Telegraph)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – The co.’s incoming CEO is looking at the sale of tens of thousands of their mobile masts to reduce the co.’s debt , which currently stands at EUR 31bln. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

HAYS (HAS LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT HSBC

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) - Geely refutes the idea that it plans to surreptitiously build up its stake in the company, according to German Press. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – The co. is to recall more than 139k 3-series cars in China due to air-conditioning problems. (Newswires)

Linde (LIN GY) - Praxair (PX) might have to offload their entire overlapping business in order to gain FTC approval for their deal with Linde, according to MLex. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The co. is planning to move more assets from England to Germany, and ringfence their UK unit post-Brexit. (FT)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – The co.’s supervisory board is to meet on Friday to discuss CEO Stadler’s future. (Spiegel)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hochtief (HOT GY) – Cimic, the co.’s Australian subsidiary, has won a AUD 420mln contact extension. (Newswires)

Uniper (UN01 GY) – The co. has mandated Rothschild to look at the sale of their French unit, according to sources. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

HENKEL (HEN GY) DOWNGARDED TO MARKET-PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – The co. could reach a deal in the coming days to sell its Magneti Marelli unit to KKR, with KKR offering below USD 5bln for it. (Il Sole)

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Italian PM Conte has repeated the Govts. Intention to revoke Autostrade’s motorway concession. (Newswires)

Poste Italiane (PST IM) – The Italian Govt. is looking at a plan where Poste Italiane and the state-owned railway group would purchase Alitalia so as to prepare it for a partnership with a rival. (Il Sole)

Argenx (ARGX BB) – The co. has reported positive top-line results for a phase 2 proof-of-concept trial of Efgartigimod in primary immune thrombocytopenia. (Newswires)

SMI

UBS (UBSG SW) – The bank’s CEO said they received licenses to distribute funds and insurance in China. (Newswires)

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – Finma have said they have found deficiencies in the anti-money laundering processes at the co. This relates to due diligence obligations for corruption in FIFA, Petrobras and PDVSA. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

ELISA (ELISA FH) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

US

* SPX +0.01% at  2904, NDX -0.2% at 7546, DJI 0.03% at 26154. SECTORS: Energy +0.56%, Materials +0.02%, Industrials +0.56%, Cons Discretionary -0.18%, Cons Staples -0.28%, Healthcare -0.38%, Financials +0.40%, Tech 0.00%, Telecoms -0.54%, Utilities -0.52%.

*FUTURES: US equity futures were relatively rangebound throughout the early session, however after reports that US President Trump reportedly told advisers to proceed with USD 200bln in China tariffs, the indices were pressured with the ES falling ~9 points from 2909 to 2900 level where it was briefly breached to the downside.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 17th September 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week with a subdued tone after Trump reportedly told advisers to proceed with tariffs on a further USD 200bln of Chinese goods
  • China reportedly may not participate in planned trade discussions with the US if the Trump administration goes ahead with additional tariffs
  • The EU is secretly preparing to accept a frictionless Irish border after Brexit in a move that raises the prospect of PM May striking a deal by the end of the year
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ CPI, US NY Fed manufacturing, ECB’s Coeure

TRADE

US President Trump was said to want to go ahead with USD 200bln in China tariffs despite talks and told advisers to proceed with the tariffs according to reports on Friday which cited people familiar with the matter. Furthermore, separate reports over the weekend stated that the tariffs will go into effect within weeks and that an announcement could be made within days, while the tariffs are said to likely be set at about 10% but could be raised to 25% if China does not appear willing to comply to US trade demands at proposed meetings in Washington on September 27th-28th. (Newswires)

China reportedly may not participate in planned trade discussions with the US if the Trump administration goes ahead with additional tariffs. (WSJ)

The White House said US President Trump has been clear that himself and the administration will continue to take action to address China's unfair trade practices. (Newswires)

G-20 ministers issued statement which noted that they discussed ways to improve the WTO and that said there is urgent need to improve the WTO, while it also noted that they stepped up dialogue on international trade. G20 ministers also stated the EU-Mercosur free trade deal involving Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and Venezuela is 'in the final stages' of negotiation. (Newswires)


ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with a subdued tone amid the absence of Japanese participants due to public holiday and with sentiment dampened by trade concerns after US President Trump reportedly told advisers to proceed with tariffs on a further USD 200bln of Chinese goods which could be announced as early as today. Furthermore, reports noted the tariffs could be set at about 10% and raised to 25% if China shows an unwillingness to adhere to US demands at proposed meetings later this month, while China was said to consider abandoning discussions if the US proceeds with the tariffs. This pressured both ASX 200 (+0.4%) and KOSPI (-0.8%) from the open with healthcare the underperformer in Australia as the sector faces scrutiny from a royal commission inquiry, although the index later recovered amid strength in utilities, tech and financials. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.1%) were negative and took the brunt of the Trump tariff threats, while gambling stocks saw heavy losses after Macau shut down its casinos and floods hit the territory due to Typhoon Mangkhut.

PBoC skipped reverse repos and instead injected CNY 265bln via 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8509 (Prev. 6.8362)

Chinese House Prices (Aug) Y/Y 7.0% (Prev. 5.8%). (Newswires)


UK

The EU is secretly preparing to accept a frictionless Irish border after Brexit in a move that raises the prospect of PM May striking a deal by the end of the year, according to Confidential diplomatic notes seen by The Times. In a concession to British concerns, EU negotiators intend to use technological solutions to minimise customs checks between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic (Times) Further to this, the FT reported that the EU are in discussions with Brussels over allowing British officials (as opposed to EU ones), to check goods bound for Northern Ireland, in a bid to unlock stalled talks on the “backstop” plan for the Irish border. (FT)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson has continued to criticise UK PM May’s Chequers proposal by stating that May was leading the nation towards a ‘spectacular political car crash’. (Newswires)

Spain are reportedly to seek concessions concerning Gibraltar in Brexit accord, according to sources. (Newswires)

London Mayor Kahn has called for a second EU referendum, criticising the government's handling of Brexit negotiations with the EU. (BBC)

UK Environment Secretary Gove has stated that MPs could undo the Chequers deal once the UK has left the EU, adding that the PM’s proposal was the “right one for now”. (Guardian)

BoE’s Carney at last Thursday’s UK cabinet briefing, reportedly told the cabinet that the domestic economy could receive a GBP 16bln lift if PM May was able to negotiate a deal with the EU based on her Chequers proposal. (FT)

British Chambers of Commerce lowered UK 2018 GDP growth forecast to 1.1% from 1.3%. (Newswires)

UK Visa consumer spending in August rose 0.4% Y/Y in August vs. Prev. decline of 0.9% Y/Y in July. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Sep) M/M 0.7% (Prev. -2.3%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Sep) Y/Y 1.2% (Prev. 1.1%)
 

EU

A few ECB policymakers wanted last week's policy message to state that risks were tilted to the downside, according to sources. (Newswires)

ECB's Makuch said he could consider leaving position early to ensure a smooth transition prior to the next election. Furthermore, Makuch stated we’re not underestimating the risks and based on what we know now, the development is stable and risks are balanced with some downside risks to GDP growth, while he added we don’t see any reason to spread a gloomy mood or panic. (Newswires)

Spain is to propose a tax on large tech platforms and approve financial tax, while Spain is to also propose a tax increase for the highest earners and will increase pensions in line with inflation, according to PM Sanchez. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Portugal at BBB-; Outlook revised to Positive from Stable, affirmed Austria at AA+; Outlook Stable and affirmed Finland at AA+; Outlook Stable. S&P also affirmed Denmark at AAA; Outlook Stable and affirmed Luxembourg at AAA; Outlook Stable. Moody’s affirmed EU at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswire)


FX

FX markets were flat across the board amid a lack of data points and fresh news catalysts from over the weekend. This kept the DXY virtually unchanged just below the 95.00 level, while EUR/USD and GBP/USD languished near Friday’s lows and failed to make any meaningful recovery against the greenback in the aftermath of the better than expected US Industrial Production data and safe-haven flows. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was choppy around 112.00 amid the absence of Japanese participants, and CNY was pressured from the tariff fears which in turn restricted price action in the China-exposed AUD.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities lacked firm direction overnight in which WTI crude futures kept to within a tight range below short-term resistance at USD 69.00/bbl. Elsewhere, attempts to nurse some of Friday’s losses in gold were hampered as the greenback held on to recent gains, while copper underperformed with losses of nearly 1% as tariff concerns weighed on risk appetite.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (07 Sep) 1055 (Prev. 1048). (Newswires)
US Baker Hughes Oil Rig Count (07 Sep) 867 (Prev. 860)
US Baker Hughes Gas Rig Count (07 Sep) 186 (Prev. 186)

US Energy Secretary Perry said a number of things in Saudi Arabia give him confidence that they will maintain and maybe increase output, while he added that Saudi Arabia is working on a solution with Kuwait over border issue. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia Energy Minister Al-Falih and Russian counterpart Novak met over the weekend in which they pledged to continue working on cooperation. (Newswires)

The U.S. Treasury has reduced the impact of sanctions on Rusal by allowing customers to negotiate some new contracts, just as the global aluminum industry was bracing for further turmoil ahead of an Oct. 23 deadline. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran forces fired rockets towards the US embassy in Baghdad this week, while Pompeo also commented that Russia has actively worked to undermine UN sanctions on North Korea. (Newswires)
 

US

The treasury complex edged lower with the 10yr yield hitting the 3% level briefly due to the strong Uni of Mich Sentiment data, which posted above 100, the moves are also attributable to the upward revisions to retail sales. The data was all consistent with markets expectations for two more Fed rate hikes this year. Nonetheless, the yield failed to go above 3% and traded below for the rest of the trading session after the level was hit, acting as key resistance. Yields were by c.3bps at settlement whilst spreads were narrower with the exception of 2s5s which widened by less than 1bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled ticks 8 lower at 119-05+.

Fed named Mary Daly as new San Francisco President, currently Head of Research at San Francisco Fed and effective on October 1st. (Newswires)
